questions.text: Decrease in pH shifts the oxygen dissociation curve to_____

choices.text: On either side depending on other factors

questions.solution:
The pH decreasing from the normal value shifts the O2-hemoglobin dissociation curve, to the right.

Oxygen-Hb dissociation curve (OHDC)

  • This is a plot of the partial pressure of O2 and the % saturation of Hb with O2.
  • It is normally sigmoid-shape.
  • If OHDC is shifted to the right, it means that affinity of Hb for O2 has become less (which favors O2 delivery) i.e. Higher the P50. (R - Right shift Releases oxygen)

Shift to the right is caused by: (Conditions with increased requirement of O2 - metabolically active tissues)

  • Hypoxia and Hypercarbia - Metabolically active tissues utilise O2 and tissues produce CO2
  • ↓ pH - Secondary to increased CO2 production
  • ↑ in temperature, heat 
  • ↑ in 2,3-DPG - increased anaerobic glycolysis
  • Growth hormone, thyroid hormone, androgen - by increasing 2,3 DPG
  • Sickle cell anaemia - reduced affinity for O2

questions.text: The phospholipid that helps in mitochondrial function, and that is found only in the mitochondria is _______
questions.solution:
Cardiolipin is the phospholipid found only in the mitochondria. 

Cardiolipin is an important component of the inner mitochondrial membrane, where it is essential for the following:

  • Optimal function of numerous mitochondrial enzymes that are involved in mitochondrial energy metabolism.
  • Maintenance of the structure of the mitochondrial membrane.

Clinical correlate:

Decreased cardiolipin or alteration in its metabolism results in mitochondrial dysfunction seen in Barth syndrome (cardioskeletal myopathy).

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman receiving cyclosporin A after renal transplantation develops multiple and bilateral breast lumps that regress after cessation of treatment. ​Biopsy image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Almost half the women receiving cyclosporin A after renal transplantation develop multiple and bilateral fibroadenomas that regress after cessation of treatment.

Fibroadenomas are the most common benign tumor of the female breast. They are frequently multiple and bilateral and usually occur in women<30 years of age. They are called "breast mouse" due to their high mobility within the breast.

Complex fibroadenomas are grouped with “proliferative changes without atypia” and are associated with 1.5-2 times increased risk of subsequent cancer. Complex fibroadenomas contain cysts larger than 0.3 cm, sclerosing adenosis, epithelial calcifications, or papillary apocrine change.

Histological image of Fibroadenoma showing proliferation of ducts arranged in intracanalicular (compressed) and pericanalicular pattern surrounded by fibromyxoid stroma.

questions.text: A young patient presents to the dermatology OPD with a history of itchy hypopigmented patches over her chest for 6 months. A KOH mount is prepared with the skin scraping sample, which on microscopy reveals a characteristic appearance as shown in the image. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and the KOH mount preparation showing the spaghetti and meatball appearance suggest pityriasis versicolor.

Pityriasis Versicolor is a chronic superficial infection of the stratum corneum caused by Malassezia globosa and Malassezia furfur. The most common site involves the neck, chest, back, and upper arms. The lesions often appear as hypopigmented areas.

The KOH mount reveals fungal hyphae that are short and thick (like spaghetti or banana) and many variously sized spores (like meatballs or grapes) referred to as spaghetti and meatballs or bananas and grapes appearance.

Treatment includes topical azoles or terbinafine for 2 weeks.

The image below shows the hypopigmented lesions of P. versicolor over the chest.

Electron microscopic image of Malassezia furfur

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of Rivaroxaban ?
questions.solution:
Rivaroxaban is an oral direct factor Xa inhibitor. They represent a new class of oral anticoagulant drugs that do not require monitoring.

This group of drugs inhibit factor Xa in the final common pathway of clotting [conversion of Prothrombin (Factor II) to thrombin (Factor IIa)]. They are given as fixed doses and have a rapid onset of action.

Oral direct factor Xa inhibitors are indicated in:

  • Prevention of embolic stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation (without valvular heart disease)
  • Venous thromboembolic disease (VTE)
  • Postoperative thromboprophylaxis in patients undergoing hip and knee arthroplasty

Direct factor Xa inhibitors:

  • Rivaroxaban
  • Apixaban
  • Edoxaban
  • Betrixaban

Parenteral direct thrombin inhibitors:

  • Bivalirudin
  • Argatroban
  • Desirud

Note: The FDA recently approved the drug Apixaban for a new indication. The drug is now used to reduce the risk of stroke and systemic embolism in patients with nonvalvular atrial fibrillation.

Related Pearl: Classification of Anticoagulants

 

 

Classification of Anticoagulants
1) Vitamin K antagonist

Warfarin
 
2) Direct thrombin inhibitors (DTI)    Oral DTI

Dabigatran
Parenteral DTI 

Monovalent DTI- Argatroban
  Bivalent DTI- Lepirudin, Desirudin, Bivalirudin
 
3) Indirect thrombin inhibitors  Unfractionated heparin
Low molecular weight heparins  

Enoxaparin, Dalteparin, Tinzaparin
Fondaparinux
 
4) Direct Oral Factor Xa Inhibitors  Rivaroxaban, Apixaban, Edoxaban, Betrixaban

questions.text: A child who is a victim under POCSO act is brought to the department forensic medicine for age estimation. The X-ray image of the hand is shown below. What is the likely age of the child?
questions.solution:
The child's age is likely to be 13 years.

In the above X-ray image of the wrist and hand, all the carpal bones are seen. The lower epiphysis of the first metacarpal has not united with the shaft. This suggests that the age of the child is 12 to 15 years.

The age of ossification of the carpal bones:

Carpal bone Age of ossification
Capitate 1-3 months
Hamate

2-4 months
Triquetrum

2-3 years
Lunate 2-4 years
Scaphoid 4-6 years
Trapezium 4-6 years
Trapezoid 4-6 years  
Pisiform 8-12 years  

The age of fusion of joints:

Bone/ joint Maximum age at fusion

Elbow joint centers

Metacarpals

 16 years
Wrist joint centers 19 years
Hip bone centers 22 years

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy comes with complaints of right ear pain, difficulty in opening the mouth, painful swallowing, and fever. The oral cavity examination reveals the following. The external facial examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is likely?
questions.solution:
The image shows quinsy also known as a peritonsillar abscess. 

It is the collection of pus between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx.

The clinical features are sore throat/ dysphagia, drooling of saliva, trismus, ipsilateral otalgia, and fever. 

The management of quinsy is by antibiotics and incision & drainage to drain the abscess followed by interval tonsillectomy 6 weeks later.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient comes with complaints of progressive weakness as the day progresses. He is found to have antibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. Which is the most common ocular finding in this disease?
questions.solution:
Ptosis is the most common ocular feature in myasthenia gravis (MG).

MG is an autoimmune disorder most commonly caused by antibodies against the acetylcholine receptor (AChR). These antibodies cause damage to the postsynaptic muscle membrane and increased endocytosis of the AChR.

Patients usually present with weakness and fatiguability of the muscles, which increases on repeated use or late in the day and improves on rest. The cranial muscles, particularly the eyelids and extraocular muscles are involved early in the course of MG. Diplopia and ptosis are common initial complaints. When MG becomes generalized, the proximal muscles of the limbs are affected first. Despite the muscle weakness, the deep tendon reflexes remain normal.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most universally accepted health status indicator?
questions.solution:
Infant mortality rate (IMR) is the most universally accepted health status indicator of the whole population and of the socio-economic status in which they live.

Infant mortality rate (IMR)= Number of deaths in the first year of life/Number of live births x 1000

It is a sensitive indicator of the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of health care. It is also among the best indicators of state failure.

The best indicator of socio-economic development is the under-5 mortality rate.

questions.text: The graph in the image shows the six year probability of developing myocardial infarction per 1000 men due to the risk factors of smoking and elevated serum cholesterol, at various levels of systolic blood pressure. Identify the correct description for curves a, b, c, and d with respect to the risk factors from the options given below:

choices.text: Curve b: Denotes the risk with elevated serum cholesterol.
Curve c: Denotes the risk in smokers.
Curve d: Denotes the risk with smoking and elevated serum cholesterol.
All of the above options are true.

questions.solution:
The curve (d) denotes the increment in the risk of myocardial infarction due to the additive effects of smoking and elevated serum cholesterol. 

The graph shows the risks of smoking and raised serum cholesterol alone and the additive effects of smoking, serum cholesterol and raised blood pressure in increasing the probability of myocardial infarction. Thus, the effects of these risk factors are synergistic.

The vertical axis gives the probability of myocardial infarction per 1000 mean with a given SBP

The curves denote:

Curve a: Risk in absence of smoking and absence of elevated serum cholesterol.

Curve b: Risk in smokers.

Curve c: Risk with elevated serum cholesterol.

Curve d: Risk with smoking and elevated serum cholesterol.

questions.text: All of the following are contraindications of IUD usage except:
questions.solution:
Cardiac problems is not a contraindication in IUD usage.

 

IUD Usage
Absolute contraindications Relative contraindications

suspected pregnancy,

PID,

vaginal bleeding of unknown etiology,

Carcinoma cervix/uterus/adnexa/other pelvic tumors,

previous ectopic pregnancy.

anemia,

menorrhagia,

history of PID since the last pregnancy,

purulent cervical discharge, distortions of the uterine cavity due to fibroids,

uterine malformations,

unmotivated person. 

Hence, the best answer here is cardiac problems.

questions.text: Cryoprecipitate has all the following components except
questions.solution:
Cryoprecipitate does not contain factor IX.

Components of cryoprecipitate are

  • Factor VIII
  • Factor XIII
  • Fibrinogen
  • Fibronectin
  • Von Willebrand factor

Therefore it can be used in patients with hemophilia A, factor XIII deficiency, hypofibrinogenemia, and von Willebrand disease.

Related Pearl: Blood components

Component Volume     (1 unit) Content Clinical response, increase in  Storage temperature Shelf-life
Whole blood 450 ml RBCs, platelets, plasma Hb and plasma volume    
Packed red blood cells (PRBCs) 180 ml RBCs

Hb by 1 g/dl

Hematocrit by 3%

1° to 6°C

ACD/CPD-21 days, CPD-A-35 days, additive-42 days
Random donor platelets (RDP) 50-70 ml Platelets platelet count by 5000-10,000/µL 20 to 24°C 5 days
Single donor apheretic platelets (SDP*) 200-400 ml Platelets platelet count by 30,000/µL
Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) 200-250 ml Coagulation factors, protein C, protein S, anti thrombin coagulation factors by 2% -18 to -30°C 1 year
Cryoprecipitate 10-15 ml fibrinogen, factor VIII, VWF 80 IU Factor VIII -18 °C 1 years

 

*SDP is obtained by collecting multiple units of platelets from a single donor using apheretic technology. 

1 SDP = 6 RDP

questions.text: Which of the following is the first line of treatment for von Willebrand disease?
questions.solution:
Desmopressin is the first line of treatment for von Willebrand disease.

Desmopressin (DDAVP) acts on endothelial V2 receptors causing the release of VWF and factor VIII from endothelial stores.

DDAVP can be given intravenously or by an intranasal spray. Side effects: Tachyphylaxis and hyponatremia. 

VWF concentrate is given for severe diseases or for major procedures.

Antifibrinolytic therapy (tranexamic acid or ε-aminocaproic acid) is used for the prevention and treatment of mucosal bleeding.

questions.text: A postgraduate student is assisting in the emergency trauma surgery of an HIV-infected person noted to have severe oropharyngeal candidiasis. He suffers a bleeding puncture wound on his right index finger, through the glove. Which of the following is correct regarding post-exposure prophylaxis for HIV in this situation?
questions.solution:
Recommended Post-exposure prophylaxis(PEP) is a three drug regimen which includes Lamivudine 300mg , Tenofovir 300mg and Dolutegravir 50mg. A regimen for post-exposure prophylaxis for HIV with two ARV drugs is effective, but three drugs are preferred. The PEP must be initiated ideally within 2 hours and certainly within 72 hours. WHO recommended PEP regimen:

Drug combination Recommendation for PEP Duration
Tenofovir (TDF) 300mg + Lamivudine(3TC) 300mg + Dolutegravir (DTG) 50mg    Once daily 4 weeks

questions.text: A 66-year-old chronic smoker who is diagnosed with small cell carcinoma of the lung presents to the ER with complaints of nausea, confusion,  and dizziness. After the initial workup, he is diagnosed to have the syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH). The SIADH is characterized by:

choices.text: Hyponatremia and urine sodium excretion > 20 mEq/L
Hypernatremia and urine sodium excretion > 20 mEq/L

questions.solution:
The syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH) is associated with increased urinary excretion of sodium, thereby leading to hyponatremia and urine sodium excretion > 20 mEq/L.

 Small cell lung cancer is commonly associated with SIADH due to the ectopic release of antidiuretic hormone. 

Patients usually present with hyponatremia with a euvolemic status. If hyponatremia develops acutely, signs and symptoms may include mild headache, confusion, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, coma, and convulsions. Chronic hyponatremia allows cerebral adaptation, and the patients are asymptomatic despite the hyponatremia.

Laboratory findings in SIADH include:

  • Hyponatremia: serum Na+<135 mEq/L
  • Urinary loss of Na+ >25 mEq per day or >40 mEq/L 
  • Urinary osmolality is >100 mOsm/kg
  • Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels are low, usually <10 mg/dL
  • Serum K+ and serum bicarbonate are normal

questions.text: What is the size of the given blade used for incision and drainage of a superficial abscess?
questions.solution:
The blade shown in the image is of the size 11.

The 11-blade is used for skin incisions (eg. incision and drainage) and arteriotomy

The 22-blade is often used for abdominal incisions

15-blade for minor surgical procedures

questions.text: Identify the type of suturing shown below.
questions.solution:
The image shows the technique of interrupted Sutures. Here each suture should reach into the depths of the wound and be placed at right angles to the axis of the wound.

Option B: Mattress suture produce an accurate approximation of wound edges, especially when the edges to be anastomosed are irregular. The initial suture is inserted as for an interrupted suture, but then the needle either moves horizontally or vertically and traverses both edges of the wound once again as seen in the picture below.

Option C: Continuous Suture: For a continuous suture, the first suture is inserted in an identical manner to an interrupted suture, but the rest of the sutures are inserted in a continuous manner until the far end of the wound is reached.

Option D: Subcuticular Sutures: Small bites of the subcuticular tissues are taken on alternate sites of the wound and then gently pulled together thus approximating the wound edges without the risk of the cross-hatched markings of interrupted sutures. This technique is used in the skin where a cosmetic appearance is important and where the skin edges may be approximated easily.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a history of greenish discharge from the nipple for the past 1 month. Personal history is significant for cigarette smoking. On compression of her breast, greenish discharge from multiple ducts was observed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of a patient with greenish discharge from multiple ducts is duct ectasia. 

Duct ectasia is the dilatation of breast ducts. It is the most common cause of nipple discharge in nonlactating women. This condition is associated with smoking and diabetes.

The initial stage of this disease consists of dilatation of one or more lactiferous ducts. These ducts get filled with stagnant brown or green colored secretions. In the later stages, the accumulation of fluid in the lactiferous ducts leads to infection and inflammation, causing periductal mastitis. The infections are most often mixed infections of aerobic and anaerobic flora of the skin.

Patients may present with nipple discharge, abscess, fistula or nipple retraction.

Related Pearl: Discharges from the nipple

Discharges from the nipple:

Discharge from the surface

  • Paget’s disease
  • Skin diseases (eczema, psoriasis)
  • Rare causes (e.g., chancre)

Discharge from a single duct

  • Blood-stained
    • Intraductal papilloma
    • Intraductal carcinoma
    • Duct ectasia
  • Serous (any colour)
    • Fibrocystic disease
    • Duct ectasia
    • Carcinoma

Discharge from more than one duct

  • Blood-stained
    • Carcinoma
    • Ectasia
    • Fibrocystic disease
  • Black or green
    • Duct ectasia
  • Purulent
    • Infection
  • Serous
    • Fibrocystic disease
    • Duct ectasia
    • Carcinoma
  • Milk:
    • Lactation
    • Rare causes (hypothyroidism, pituitary tumour)

Remember:

  • The most common cause of blood-stained discharge from single duct is duct papilloma.
  • The most common cause of blood-stained discharge from multiple ducts is duct carcinoma.
  • The most common cause of serous discharge from the breast is fibrocystic disease of breast.

questions.text: The most common tumor of the parotid gland is ______.
questions.solution:
The most common tumor of the parotid gland is pleomorphic adenoma.

  • 80 to 90% of parotid gland tumors are benign; most commonly, they are pleomorphic adenomas.
  • Most commonly, they arise from the superficial lobe, and all tumors of the superficial lobe of the parotid gland should be managed by superficial parotidectomy.
  • Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor of the parotid gland.

Pleomorphic adenoma:

  • Slowly growing benign tumor
  • Unicentric in origin
  • Pseudo-capsule present
  • Potentially malignant
  • Possibility of protrusion of fringes of the tumor mass through the capsule
  • Radioresistant
  • Usually affects adults, females > males
  • Slowly growing, painless swelling
  • Well-defined margins
  • Lobulated, firm, elastic-to-hard consistency
  • Free from deeper structures
  • No facial nerve involvement
  • Deep lobe pushes tonsils and faucial pillars

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: Which of the following effects of puberty are not mediated by estrogen?
questions.solution:
Pubarche or development of axillary and pubic hair is not mediated by estrogen. It occurs due to testosterone in both sexes.

Puberty in females involves the beginning of menstrual cycles (menarche), breast development (thelarche), and an increase in adrenal androgen secretion (adrenarche).

Effects of Estrogen:

  • Estradiol induces the development of secondary sex characteristics, including the breasts and reproductive tract, and increased fat in the hips.
  • Estrogens also regulate the growth spurt at puberty, vaginal cornification, and cervical mucus production, induce closure of the epiphyses.
  • Estrogen has a positive effect in maintaining bone formation and can antagonize the degrading actions of parathyroid hormone on bone.

questions.text: Identify the type of adherent placenta___
questions.solution:
The given illustration with villi invading the myometrium depicts placenta increta.

Types of adherent placenta:

  • Placenta accreta: Indicates that villi are attached to the myometrium.
  • Placenta increta: Villi actually invade the myometrium.
  • Placenta percreta: Defines villi that penetrate through the myometrium and to or through the serosa.

questions.text: Diagnostic laparoscopy was performed on a patient who presented with infertility. During the procedure, the surgeon notices powder burn spots over the pelvic viscera. The diagnosis would be?
questions.solution:
Powder burn spots over pelvic viscera is seen in pelvic endometriosis. 

Typically, there are small black dots, the so-called powder burns/gunshot appearance seen on the serosal surfaces of the peritoneum. They are black, dark brown, or bluish nodules or can be small cysts containing old hemorrhage surrounded by a variable degree of fibrosis.

Other pathology in Endometriosis:

  • Peritoneal cavity: contains yellowish-brown fluid which has prostaglandins responsible for the pain of endometriosis.
  • Ovary: Chocolate cyst (True cyst with columnar epithelium lining)

Powder burn appearance:

questions.text: Identify the birth defect.
questions.solution:
The above image depicts omphalocele.

Omphalocele is a midline abdominal defect and is covered by peritoneal or umbilical sac. Babies born with omphalocele should be thouroughly evaluated for other associated congenital anamolies like cardiac anamolies, neural tube defect and trisomies.

Management includes IV fluids, IV antibiotics, preservation of sac with a sterile saline gauze/bowel bag followed by surgical closure.

Related Pearl: Difference between gastroschisis and omphalocele

Characteristic Gastroschisis Omphalocele
Defect size (diameter) 2-3 cm 2-15 cm
Sac Never Always, may be ruptured
Gestational age Prematurity Term
Umbilical cord Adjacent to the defect (defect is seen usually on its right side)  Attached to sac
Herniated viscera Small bowel, stomach, colon Small bowel, stomach, colon, liver
Malrotation Yes Yes
Bowel character Inflammatory, edematous Normal
Enternal nutrition Delayed Normal
Associated abnormalities Uncommon (10% atresia) Common (50%)

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presented to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. The radiograph of his pelvis is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis of the condition given in the picture is posterior dislocation of left hip joint.

The radiograph shows the following findings:

  • The femoral head is displaced superiorly and laterally
  • The left femoral head appears slightly smaller than the right femoral head
  • The limb is adducted and internally rotated

questions.text: Corkscrew appearance of the esophagus is seen in:
questions.solution:
The corkscrew appearance of the esophagus is seen in diffuse esophageal spasm.

  • Diffuse/distal esophageal spasm (DES) is a motility disorder of the esophagus.
  • On barium swallow, DES may appear as a corkscrew or rosary bead esophagus, but this is uncommon.
  • Manometry is the gold-standard diagnostic test.

In esophageal carcinoma barium study will show irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction and shouldered margins.

Double-contrast esophagram shows a large, flat ulceration (arrow) in the distal esophagus in a patient with CMV esophagitis.

questions.text: Flashback phenomenon is more commonly seen with _____.
questions.solution:
Flashback phenomenon is more commonly seen with cannabis.

Flashback phenomenon:

A person experiences sensations related to substance intoxication after the short-term effects of the substance have disappeared. That is person relives the substance(cannabis) use experience without consuming it.

It is also seen in Lysergic acid diethylamide(LSD), phencyclidine which are hallucinogens.

questions.text: A 28-year-old G2P1L1, previous lower segment cesarean section, is brought to the hospital in an emergency with abdominal pain, hematuria, and vaginal bleeding. On examination, fetal bradycardia is seen and the fetal heart rate tracing is non-reassuring. The anesthetic technique of choice in this situation is____
questions.solution:
A case of previous LSCS with symptoms of abdominal pain, hematuria and signs of fetal bradycardia, and a non-reassuring fetal heart rate tracing is suggestive of uterine scar dehiscence. So, emergency cesarean section is indicated.

General anesthesia is the preferred choice considering the emergency nature of surgery and the possibility of hemodynamic instability of impending uterine rupture.

General anesthesia is preferred in certain emergency conditions such as:

  • Massive bleeding (placenta previa or accreta, abruption placentae, or uterine rupture)
  • Coagulopathy
  • Hemodynamic instabilty
  • Severe fetal distress

questions.text: All are true regarding secondary syphilis except _______

choices.text: Coppery red rash is present that is nonpruritic
Vesicles are a characteristic feature of secondary syphilis

questions.solution:
Vesiculobullous lesions are a feature of early congenital syphilis. Secondary syphilis is the stage when generalized manifestations occur on the skin and mucous membranes, 8 weeks after infection.

Rashes in secondary syphilis have three common features:

  • The rashes do not itch, are coppery red and are symmetrically distributed.

Other Features of Secondary Syphilis are:

  • Papular rash involving palms and soles. As the roseolar rash fades, it may leave behind hypopigmentation. This type of leukoderma syphiliticum is most commonly located on the back or sides of the neck and was formerly known as the ‘necklace of Venus’.
  • On the genitals, for example, at the penoscrotal junction, there may be small eroded papules flush with the skin or hypertrophic, coalesced papules (condylomata lata).
  • Syphilitic alopecia: Patchy hair loss is characteristic of syphilis giving a ‘moth‐eaten’ patches of semi‐baldness
  • Generalised diffuse lymphadenopathy and other systemic features of secondary syphilis include panuveitis, periostitis and joint effusions, glomerulonephritis, hepatitis, gastritis and myocarditis.

The lesions of secondary syphilis resolve spontaneously in a variable time period and most patients enter the latency stage within the first year of infection.

Image: Syphilitic rash on Palms

Image: Moth eaten Alopecia

questions.text: The Nuclear scan used for the detection of Meckel’s diverticulum:
questions.solution:
• Tc 99m Pertechnetate is used for detection of Meckel's diverticulum.
  • Uses of Tc-99m pertechnetate:
    • Thyroid imaging
    • Meckel scan
    • Testicle imaging
    • Parathyroid imaging for distinguishing from thyroid gland
    • Gastric emptying studies, intestinal and rectal functional studies.

questions.text: Area marked in the given image is supplied by dermatome number?
questions.solution:
The marked dermatome which includes the umbilicus is supplied by T10.

The dermatomal distribution of the abdominal region is as follows: 

  • T7, T8, T9 - supplies skin from the xiphoid process to just above the umbilicus.
  • T10 - supplies skin around the umbilicus.
  • T11, T12 - supplies skin below the umbilicus upto the suprapubic region.
  • L1 - supplies skin around the genitalia and upper medial thigh.
